dcterms:title: Impaired iron recycling from erythrocytes is an early hallmark of aging
dcterms:abstract: Aging affects iron homeostasis, as evidenced by tissue iron loading and anemia in the elderly. Iron needs in mammals are met primarily by iron recycling from senescent red blood cells (RBCs), chiefly accomplished by splenic red pulp macrophages (RPMs). Here, we found that 10-11-month-old female mice exhibit iron loading in RPMs, largely due to a drop in iron exporter ferroportin, which diminishes their erythrophagocytosis capacity and lysosomal activity. We further found that feeding mice an iron-reduced diet alleviates iron accumulation in RPMs and improves their function, thus demonstrating that dietary iron reduction can rejuvenate RPMs and enhance iron turnover efficacy.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Introduction
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: Sufficient iron supplies are critical for the proper functioning of cells and organisms. At the systemic level, 80% of circulating iron is utilized for hemoglobin synthesis during the daily generation of approximately 200 billion RBCs. Recently, it has been shown that macrophages play a key role in maintaining iron homeostasis by recycling iron from senescent RBCs...

fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: We used young (2-3-month-old) and aged (10-11-month-old) C57BL/6J mice fed either a standard iron diet or an iron-reduced diet to evaluate the effects on RPM functions.
